title-group.article-title: STING and Nonnecroptotic MLKL‐Mediated Mechanisms Improve Dendritic Cell Maturation and Killing of Cancer Cells

aff.named-content: Department of Health Science and Technology

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 The Author(s). European Journal of Immunology published by Wiley‐VCH GmbH

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Activation of the cGAS‐STING pathway plays an important role in antitumor immunity through maturation of tumor‐infiltrating DCs. DCs engulf extracellular DNA released by dying cancer cells, supporting activation of the cGAS‐STING pathway and concomitant DC maturation. Extracellular DNA in the tumor microenvironment is primarily derived from cells undergoing uncontrolled necrosis or programmed inflammatory death, such as necroptosis, which can be induced when apoptosis pathways are inhibited. Here, we report that caspase inhibition primes activation of a RIPK1/3, MLKL, and STING signaling axis in DCs, resulting in maturation without the need for any further maturation stimuli such as LPS or TNF‐α. Notably, these signaling events do not induce DC death, indicating a nonnecroptotic role of the RIPK1‐RIPK3‐MLKL pathway and novel crosstalk with the STING pathway. Caspase inhibition in DC/cancer cell co‐cultures results in DC maturation, inducing TNF‐α secretion, which delivers the co‐signal to induce cancer cell necroptosis. In summary, we find a collaborative mechanism of the STING and necroptosis pathway in DC maturation, and that activation of the necroptosis pathway has opposite effects on cancer cells and DCs, proposing a possibility for new targets in cancer immunotherapy.

In this study, we show that caspase‐8 inhibition induce maturation in DCs through a synergistic crosstalk between the STING signaling pathway and RIPK1‐RIPK3‐MLKL pathway, without induction of cell death in the DCs. The mature DCs secrete TNF‐α that induces cancer cell death in DC/cancer cell co‐cultures upon concomitant caspase‐8 inhibition.

p.mixed-citation: T. S.Jensen, M. F.Laursen, L.Schort, et al. “STING and Nonnecroptotic MLKL‐Mediated Mechanisms Improve Dendritic Cell Maturation and Killing of Cancer Cells.” European Journal of Immunology55, no. 9 (2025): 55, e70044. 10.1002/eji.7004440899086PMC12405974

fn.p: Martin R. Jakobsen and Emil Kofod‐Olsen contributed equally to this work.
Funding: Novo Nordisk Fonden. Fabrikant Einar Willumsens Mindelegat. Eva og Henry Frenkels Mindelegat. Else og Mogens Wedell‐Wedellborgs Fond.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As a tumor develops, substantial cell death, including necrosis, will occur due to poor vascularization, rapid cell growth, hypoxia, and lack of nutrients [1]. Cancer cells can also die through various forms of regulated cell death, notably apoptosis or programmed immunogenic cell death (ICD), such as necroptosis and pyroptosis [2]. Whereas apoptosis usually is immunologically silent, ICD leads to the release of damage‐associated molecular patterns (DAMPs), such as double‐stranded DNA (dsDNA) and nuclear proteins, leading to inflammation and ultimately to an adaptive response against tumor‐associated and tumor‐specific antigens [3, 4].

Engagement of death receptors supports the initiation of apoptosis through activation of caspase‐8. If caspase‐8 is inhibited, receptor‐interacting serine/threonine protein kinase (RIPK)‐1 will recruit and phosphorylate RIPK3, which then binds and phosphorylates mixed‐lineage kinase domain‐like protein (MLKL) [4, 5]. MLKL is the executor of necroptosis, and when phosphorylated by RIPK3, it undergoes conformational change, resulting in oligomerization and translocation to the plasma membrane. Subsequently, this will induce pore formation and leakage of intracellular DAMPs, such as dsDNA, to the surroundings [6].

The RIPK1‐RIPK3‐MLKL pathway has mainly been investigated as a backup cell death mechanism to counteract viral infections that block apoptosis. However, increasing evidence shows that proteins involved in necroptosis signaling have functions beyond induction of necroptosis, and there is a link between proteins from the necroptosis pathway and the type I interferon (IFN‐I) response, where RIPK1 and RIPK3 positively regulate the IFN‐I response to LPS in macrophages [7, 8]. Furthermore, IFN‐I has been shown to be required for sufficient RIPK3 activation for necroptosis execution [9], and MLKL is an interferon‐stimulated gene (ISG); thus, its expression will depend on IFN‐I [6]. Besides preventing necroptosis, caspase‐8 can cleave RIPK1 and appear to influence stimulator of interferon genes (STING) and TANK‐binding kinase 1 (TBK1) activity, which is constitutively active in caspase‐8 KO mice [10, 11, 12].

Cancer cells dying through ICD may leak DNA into the tumor microenvironment (TME), which can activate nearby immune cells, including dendritic cells (DCs), through the detection by DNA recognition receptors, especially cyclic GMP‐AMP synthase (cGAS) [13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19]. Binding of DNA to cGAS leads to a conformational change, enabling it to catalyze the formation of the second messenger, cyclic 2’3’‐GMP‐AMP (cGAMP), from GTP and ATP [20]. cGAMP is a cyclic di‐nucleotide that binds and activates STING in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) [19, 21, 22]. Upon binding of cGAMP, STING translocates to the ER‐Golgi intermediate compartments (ERGIC) and activates TBK1, leading to TBK1 auto‐phosphorylation and phosphorylation of STING and interferon regulatory factor 3 (IRF3). The phosphorylated, dimerized IRF3 translocates to the nucleus where it induces transcription of IFN‐I, and subsequently, ISGs [21, 23].

Cancer cells may also produce cGAMP as a response to DNA that may build up in the cytosol due to chromosomal instability [15, 16]. Interestingly, cGAMP released from irradiated tumors has been shown to be essential for activation of tumor‐infiltrating DCs, and the success of an antitumor immune response is dependent on activation of DCs and their ability to induce a strong IFN‐I response as well as activation of cytotoxic T cells [15, 24].

Thus, it is clear that the necroptosis pathway and STING pathway interact; however, the relationship between these two pathways is still largely unresolved and has so far not been investigated in DCs.

Here we show that DCs can undergo maturation if caspases are inhibited, without the need for other maturation stimuli. We show that the maturation results from activation through a mechanism that requires the activity of STING as well as the RIPK1‐RIPK3‐MLKL signaling pathway through a necroptosis‐independent function of MLKL. We further show that inhibition of caspases in DC/cancer cell co‐cultures leads to DC maturation and drives cancer cell death, caused by the combination of caspase inhibition in the cancer cells and TNF‐α released from the activated DCs.

sec.title: Caspase Inhibition Drives Dendritic Cell Maturation
sec.p: To investigate if caspase inhibition in dendritic cells influences their activation, we treated murine bone marrow‐derived dendritic cells (BMDCs) with increasing amounts of zVAD‐fmk (zVAD) and analyzed the expression of maturation markers MHC‐II, CD86, and CD40 (Figure 1A–C). The expression of all maturation markers was seen to increase in a dose‐dependent manner (Figure 1C), and we observed high viability in all tested concentrations, although with a slight decrease in cultures receiving the highest concentration (Figure 1D). This was most likely caused by the high dosage of DMSO solvent used for zVAD dissolution (Figure 1A), as maturation of the DCs was not induced when treating with DMSO alone (Figure S1B). To rule out that cell death during differentiation led to increased maturation, we treated BMDCs with zVAD at days 8, 9, and 10 during differentiation. Treatment led to upregulated maturation markers in an equal amount at all three time points, which was similar to the maturation caused by LPS, independent of the number of dead cells in the culture (Figure 1E,F). Furthermore, DNase I treatment did not inhibit the maturation in BMDCs, indicating that the maturation is independent of DNA released from dying cells (Figure S1C). The same degree of DC maturation in response to zVAD could be confirmed in human monocyte‐derived dendritic cells (moDCs) (Figure S1D). Collectively, this shows that DCs mature in response to caspase inhibition, independent of the viability in cultures.

caption.p: DCs mature in response to zVAD treatment. (A) Flow cytometry gating strategy for identification of viable BMDCs. (B) Histograms of the maturation markers MHC‐II, CD86, and CD40 on BMDCs in untreated (UT, light grey), 10 µM zVAD‐treated (zVAD, red), and 100 ng/mL LPS‐treated (LPS, dark grey). (C) Maturation markers MHC‐II, CD86, and CD40 on BMDCs treated with zVAD at indicated concentrations for 24 h. (D) Viability of the BMDCs in (C), measured using eFluor780. (E) BMDCs treated with 10 µM zVAD (red) or 100 ng/mL LPS (dark grey) at day 8, 9, and 10 post‐bone marrow cell‐seeding, and analyzed by flow cytometry with antibodies against the maturation markers MHC‐II, CD86, and CD40. (F) Viability of the BMDCs in (E), measured using eFluor780. All data in (C, E) are shown as fold induction of MFI compared with UT, and dotted line represents the baseline. Error bars show the mean with SEM from triplicate. Experiments were performed at least two times independently with biological replicates (B–D: n = 3; E–F: n = 6) with similar results. Statistical analysis in (C, E) was done using one‐way ANOVA with Tukey's multiple comparisons. ns: not significant, *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001, and ****p < 0.0001.

sec.title: zVAD‐Driven Dendritic Cell Maturation Is Dependent on STING Signaling
sec.p: It has recently been shown that inhibition of caspases using zVAD in combination with LPS leads to higher IFN‐I production in macrophages than LPS alone, and this boost seems dependent on STING expression, ultimately resulting in necroptotic cell death [7]. To investigate if the observed zVAD‐induced DC maturation was dependent on STING activation, we stimulated WT and STING KO BMDCs with cGAMP, zVAD, or LPS and analyzed the DC maturation. Indeed, STING‐deficient BMDCs failed to respond to both cGAMP and zVAD stimulation but reacted similarly to WT cells when stimulated with LPS (Figure 2A,B). Next, we assessed if a combination of zVAD and cGAMP could activate THP‐1‐derived macrophages. WT and STING KO THP‐1‐derived macrophages were stimulated with zVAD, cGAMP, or zVAD + cGAMP for 24 h, followed by analysis of IFN‐I secretion. Cells treated with zVAD alone showed a small, but insignificant increase in IFN‐I secretion, whereas cGAMP led to a significant activation, which was greatly enhanced by combining zVAD and cGAMP, whereas IFN‐I secretion was completely absent in stimulated STING KO cells (Figure 2C,D).

caption.p: zVAD‐induced DC maturation is dependent on STING expression. (A–B) C57BL/6 WT BMDCs (A) and Tmem ‐/‐ BMDCs (STING KO) (B) treated with 10 µM zVAD, 5 µM cGAMP, or 100 ng/mL LPS for 24 h, followed by flow cytometry against maturation markers MHC‐II, CD86, and CD40. (C–D) Macrophages generated from WT (C) and STING KO (D) THP‐1 macrophages, treated with 10 µM zVAD, 5 µM Cgamp, or zVAD + cGAMP for 24 h, followed by IFN‐I measurements using the HEK‐Blue IFN‐α/β assay. (E) BMDCs treated with 10 µM zVAD, 5 µM cGAMP, or zVAD + cGAMP for the indicated time points and analyzed by Western blotting with antibodies against phosphorylated STING (pSTING), STING, phosphorylated TBK1 (pTBK1), TBK1, and GAPDH. (F) BALB/c BMDCs treated with 10 µM zVAD, 5 µM cGAMP, zVAD + cGAMP, 100 ng/mL LPS, or zVAD + LPS for 24 h and analyzed by flow cytometry against maturation markers MHC‐II, CD86, and CD40. All data in (A, B, F) are shown as fold induction of MFI compared with UT, shown by dotted lines. Error bars show the mean with SEM from triplicate. Western blots show one experiment with pooled triplicates. Experiments were performed at least two times independently with biological replicates (A: n = 2; B, D–F: n = 3; C: n = 4) with similar results. Statistical analysis in (A–D, F) was done using one‐way ANOVA with Tukey's multiple comparisons. ns: not significant, *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001, and ****p < 0.0001.

sec.p: Since zVAD alone was able to induce a STING‐dependent maturation of BMDCs, we evaluated the phosphorylation status of STING and TBK1 in BMDCs treated with zVAD, cGAMP, or zVAD + cGAMP in a time series, using Western blotting. BMDCs treated with zVAD alone did not have any observable phosphorylation of either STING or TBK1, whereas cGAMP stimulation, as expected, led to both STING and TBK1 phosphorylation, which declined after 8 h (Figure 2E). Remarkably, when combining zVAD and cGAMP, both STING and TBK1 phosphorylation were sustained at a high level, even after 24 h (Figure 2E). Overall, these findings indicate that maturation induced by zVAD is dependent on STING. It only minimally impacts STING activity itself but amplifies cGAMP‐mediated STING activation. To determine if the observed effects of zVAD treatment were due to caspase‐8 activity, we treated BMDCs with the specific caspase‐8 inhibitor II and compared this with zVAD treatment. BMDCs treated with caspase‐8 inhibitor showed maturation similar to the observations with zVAD, supporting that the mode‐of‐action is caspase‐8 driven (Figure S2A). Like zVAD, the caspase‐8 inhibitor did not influence viability (Figure S2B). If zVAD could influence the sensitivity of STING to cGAMP treatment, we should see an increase in DC maturation in co‐treated cells. Indeed, BMDCs showed an increase in maturation marker expression when treated with zVAD + cGAMP relative to mono‐treatment with either one alone (Figure 2F).

Surprisingly, we did not observe degradation of total STING following its activation, which has previously been described in different cell lines, including moDCs [25, 26]. To rule out that this did not result from erroneous antibody staining caused by the anti‐STING antibody used, we stripped and re‐probed the same membranes with another anti‐STING antibody, which led to the same result (Figure S3A).

sec.title: zVAD‐Induced Maturation Is Dependent on RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL Activity, Which Do Not Influence Viability
sec.p: It has previously been shown that RIPK1 can interact with the STING pathway in macrophages [10]. We set out to investigate whether the zVAD‐induced DC maturation was dependent on RIPK1. BMDCs were pretreated with the RIPK1 inhibitor necrostatin‐1 (nec‐1) for 1 h, followed by treatment with zVAD for an additional 24 h and subsequent measurement of maturation marker expression. Nec‐1 treatment resulted in decreased expression of all maturation markers, indicating that RIPK1 activity was needed for zVAD‐induced maturation (Figure 3A). The same dependency could also be found in moDCs (Figure S4). Since RIPK1 activity is regulated by phosphorylation, we performed RIPK1‐phosphorylation WB on lysates from zVAD‐treated BMDCs at various timepoints. RIPK1 was phosphorylated after 4 h of zVAD stimulation, thus confirming an involvement of RIPK1 in the observed DC maturation (Figure 3B). If RIPK1 is activated, caspase inhibition should lead to RIPK1‐mediated phosphorylation of RIPK3 [4]. To assess if this was also the case in the DCs, we measured RIPK3 phosphorylation and likewise found RIPK3 phosphorylation starting 4 h poststimulation (Figure 3B).

caption.p: zVAD‐induced DC maturation is dependent on RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL. (A) BALB/c BMDCs treated with 10 µM zVAD and 10 µM of the RIPK1 inhibitor necrostatin‐1 (Nec‐1) or 100 ng/mL LPS and then analyzed by flow cytometry with antibodies against the maturation markers MHC‐II and CD86. (B) BALB/c BMDCs treated with 10 µM zVAD for indicated time points and analyzed by Western blotting with antibodies against phosphorylated RIPK1 (pRIPK1), RIPK1, phosphorylated RIPK3 (pRIPK3), RIPK3, and GAPDH. (C) BALB/c BMDCs were treated with 10 µM zVAD, 5 µM Cgamp, or zVAD + cGAMP for indicated time points and analyzed by Western blotting with antibodies against phosphorylated MLKL (pMLKL), MLKL, and GAPDH. (D) BALB/c BMDCs treated with 10 µM zVAD and/or 0.1 µM of GW806742X for 8 h and analyzed by Western blotting with antibodies against phosphorylated MLKL (pMLKL), MLKL, phosphorylated STING (pSTING), STING, phosphorylated TBK1 (pTBK1), TBK1, and GAPDH. (E) BALB/c BMDCs treated with 10 µM zVAD and/or 0.1 µM GW806742X for 24 h and analyzed by flow cytometry using antibodies against maturation markers MHC‐II, CD86, and CD40. All data in (A, E) are shown as fold induction of MFI compared with UT. Dotted line represents the baseline. Error bars show the mean with SEM from triplicate. Experiments were performed three times independently with biological replicates (n = 3) with similar results. Western blots show one experiment with pooled biological triplicates. Statistical analysis in (A, E) was done using one‐way ANOVA with Tukey's multiple comparisons. ns: not significant, *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001, and ****p < 0.0001.

sec.p: After its phosphorylation, RIPK3 induces phosphorylation of MLKL [4]. To investigate a potential role of MLKL, we performed WB analysis of MLKL phosphorylation in BMDCs treated with zVAD, cGAMP, or zVAD + cGAMP in a time series. MLKL was phosphorylated 4 h poststimulation with zVAD and zVAD + cGAMP, similarly to RIPK1 and RIPK3 (Figure 3C; Figure S3B). MLKL phosphorylation typically leads to induction of necroptosis, but surprisingly, the DCs did not die, despite this activation, indicating an alternative function of MLKL.

Since we saw STING activation concomitantly with MLKL phosphorylation, following the same pattern as constitutive activation in co‐treated samples, we investigated whether STING activity was maintained in the absence of the active necroptosis pathway. Phosphorylations of RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL can be blocked using the inhibitor GW806742X. BMDCs were treated with zVAD with or without GW806742X for 8 h. Indeed, RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL phosphorylations were abrogated in DCs treated with zVAD in the presence of GW806742X, confirming that this inhibitor can be used to block the endpoint of the necroptosis signaling pathway (Figure S3C). We observed minimal STING phosphorylation in the zVAD‐treated cells (only visible upon long exposure of the membrane), and phosphorylation was inhibited by GW806742X (Figure 3D). We observed TBK1 phosphorylation in DCs treated with zVAD alone, and this was also abrogated, indicating a link between necroptosis signaling and STING and TBK1 phosphorylation (Figure 3D). To assess if GW806742X also influenced DC maturation after zVAD treatment, we investigated maturation marker expression on zVAD‐treated BMDCs and found that the zVAD‐induced maturation was indeed inhibited (Figure 3E). In accordance with our previous investigations, inhibiting caspase‐8 alone also led to DC maturation with STING and MLKL phosphorylation still present 18 h after stimulation (Figure S5A,B). Corresponding to our observations with zVAD, DC maturation and the STING and MLKL phosphorylation could be inhibited by GW806742X treatment.

Similarly, BMDCs secreted significantly more CXCL10 when zVAD and cGAMP were combined compared with the components alone (Figure S5C). Again, these findings were confirmed using the specific caspase‐8 inhibitor. Likewise, the CXCL10 secretion was also abrogated in the GW806742X‐treated cells, confirming a role of the RIPK1‐RIPK3‐MLKL axis in the zVAD‐induced CXCL10 secretion and DC maturation.

sec.title: Dendritic Cell and Cancer Cell Co‐Cultures with zVAD Stimulation Lead to DC Activation and Cancer Cell Death
sec.p: Since mature DCs produce a wide array of cytokines, including TNF‐α, we speculated whether zVAD‐mediated DC maturation could drive cancer cells into necroptosis through the combined effect of zVAD and DC‐derived TNF‐α. Murine L929 fibroblast cancer cells were stained with CFSE and expanded to 80% confluence. Immature BMDCs were added to the L929 culture, and the mixed culture was treated with zVAD for 24 h. The mixed culture was stained with eFluor780 viability dye as well as the DC maturation markers and analyzed by flow cytometry. The L929 cells and BMDCs were separated based on CFSE expression (Figure 4A). Cell death of L929 cells was analyzed by comparing the ratio of L929 cells and BMDCs of the mixed culture with or without zVAD stimulation, since dead L929 cells were completely disintegrated and likely rapidly phagocytized by the DCs. Markedly fewer L929 cells were detected by flow cytometry in mixed cultures with zVAD treatment, compared with the untreated mixed culture, with no loss of viability in the DCs (Figure 4C,D). DC maturation from the mixed cultures did not increase further compared with DCs only treated with zVAD, possibly influenced by the amount of time in co‐culture (Figure 4E). To assess if TNF‐α played a role in L929 cell death in co‐cultures, we treated L929 cells or co‐cultures with an anti‐TNFR1 antibody prior to treatment with zVAD. These experiments confirmed that TNFR1‐blockage was able to inhibit L929 cell death in the co‐culture treated with zVAD (Figure 4F).

caption.p: zVAD treatment of BMDC and cancer cell co‐cultures leads to increased DC activation and cancer cell death. (A) Flow cytometry gating strategy for BALB/c BMDCs and L929 cancer cells using separation based on CFSE staining of L929 cells and antibody staining for MHC‐II on BMDCs. (B) Illustration of the experimental design of (A–F). (C) Relative presence of live L929 cells in the co‐culture based on CFSE positive cells with 10 µM zVAD treatment, normalized to the co‐culture without zVAD treatment. (D) Overall viability of the L929 cells in (C) and BMDCs in (E), using eFluor780. (E) Maturation markers MHC‐II, CD86, and CD40 on BMDCs with or without L929 cells treated with 10 µM zVAD or 100 ng/mL LPS for 24 h. (F) BMDCs and L929 cells were pretreated with 100 ng/mL TNFR1 blocking antibody for 4 h, followed by 10 µM zVAD or 100 ng/mL LPS for 24 h, and viability was analyzed using eFluor780. Data in (C) are normalized to DC+L929 untreated co‐culture. Data in (E) are shown as fold induction of MFI compared with UT (E). Error bars show mean with SEM from triplicate. Experiments were performed at least two times independently with biological replicates (n = 3) with similar results. Statistical analysis in (C, E, F) was done using one‐way ANOVA with Tukey's multiple comparisons. ns: not significant, *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001, and ****p < 0.0001. Illustrations done using BioRender.

sec.p: Despite the lack of increased maturation in the co‐cultures, we speculated whether medium from L929 cells that had undergone “complete” necroptosis could lead to DC maturation. To induce necroptosis in L929 cells, we treated the cells with TNF‐α, CHX, zVAD, TNF‐α + CHX, or TNF‐α + zVAD. To confirm that the cells died from necroptosis, their viability was analyzed by flow cytometry, and the mode of cell death was analyzed by WB (anti‐PARP) 24 h posttreatment. As expected, TNF‐α + CHX induced cell death with PARP cleavage indicative of apoptosis, and TNF‐α + zVAD induced cell death without PARP cleavage indicative of necroptosis (Figure S6A–C).

Next, L929 cells were treated with zVAD, TNF‐α, or zVAD + TNF‐α for 24 h, whereafter the supernatant was transferred to BMDCs. After 24 h, DCs treated with supernatant from necroptotic cells (zVAD + TNF‐α treatment) showed upregulation of maturation markers, whereas no or little upregulation was found in DCs treated with supernatant from TNF‐α or zVAD mono‐treated L929 cells, which had a high viability (Figure 5A; Figure S6C). The same tendency was observed in moDCs (Figure S6D). To confirm that the L929 cells from co‐cultures were stimulated by factors originating from the DCs, we treated L929 cells with a combination of zVAD and conditioned medium from DC cultures that had been matured by LPS or zVAD treatment. As expected, L929 cells did not die when treated with DC‐conditioned medium or zVAD alone, whereas a combination led to a loss in viability (Figure 5B). Addition of GW806742X to the DCs prior to stimulation abrogated L929 cell death, indicating that activity of the necroptosis pathway in DCs influences the maturation‐induced release of cytokines (Figure 5B).

caption.p: Mature BMDC supernatant induces cancer cell death upon zVAD co‐treatment. (A) L929 cells were treated with 10 µM zVAD and/or 10 ng/mL TNF‐α for 24 h, followed by transfer of the supernatant to immature BALB/c BMDCs for 24 h. BMDCs were then stained for maturation markers MHC‐II, CD86, and CD40. (B) Immature BALB/c BMDCs were treated with 0.1 µM of GW806742X for 1 h followed by stimulation with 10 µM zVAD or 100 ng/mL LPS for 24 h. Subsequently, L929 cells were treated with 10 µM zVAD for 15 min followed by transfer of the DC supernatant (DC sup) to the L929 cells for 24 h. DC treatment is indicated in parentheses. L929 cells were then harvested and viability‐stained using eFluor780. All data in (A) are shown as fold induction of MFI compared with UT. The dotted line represents the baseline. Error bars show the mean with SEM from triplicate. Experiments were performed at least two independent times with biological replicates (n = 3) with similar results. Statistical analysis was done using one‐way ANOVA with Tukey's multiple comparisons. ns: not significant, *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001, and ****p < 0.0001. Illustrations done using BioRender.

sec.p: Collectively, our findings indicate that zVAD stimulation activates DCs through a mechanism dependent on the full RIPK1‐RIPK3‐MLKL signaling axis and STING signaling. At the same time, factors from the DCs will, combined with zVAD, induce necroptosis in L929 cancer cells.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In recent years, it has become evident that there is crosstalk between the cGAS‐STING pathway and proteins involved in cell death signaling [27]. Here we report that inhibiting caspases is sufficient to drive DC maturation through RIPK1‐RIPK3‐MLKL activation without induction of cell death. We further show that the effect happens through a STING‐dependent mechanism, thus coupling necroptosis signaling with STING in DCs.

Both STING signaling and cell death are influenced by the activity of caspases. Caspase‐1 has been found to cleave cGAS, thereby reducing IFN‐I synthesis [11]. Additionally, caspase‐3 has been found to reduce the effect of radiotherapy on cancer cells by abrogating the IFN‐I synthesis, making caspase inhibition a possible co‐treatment during radiotherapy [11, 28]. Caspase‐8 is constitutively active at a low level in DCs [29], and blocking this leads to RIPK1 activity in immature DCs [30]. Upon caspase inhibition, RIPK1 has been shown to function as a “docking scaffold” for TBK1, leading to elevated IFN‐I production after STING activation [10]. Other studies have investigated the interplay between these pathways in macrophages [7, 8]. Saleh et al. [7] studied caspase inhibition in macrophages and found that zVAD treatment increased the sensitivity to LPS‐induced IFN‐I synthesis, dependent on STING, RIPK1, and RIPK3 activity. In accordance with this, we find that THP‐1‐derived macrophages increase cGAMP‐induced IFN‐I secretion when caspases are inhibited. In contrast to the findings in macrophages, which required a co‐stimulus, we find that caspase inhibition on its own can drive BMDC and moDC maturation through a mechanism dependent on STING. Similarly, to the findings in macrophages, we find that zVAD‐induced DC maturation required RIPK1 and RIPK3 activity. Surprisingly, we find that DC maturation concomitantly had MLKL activation, which is contradictory to the findings in macrophages, where IFN‐I signaling is independent of MLKL activity [7]. The exact role of MLKL is still somewhat uncertain, since the use of the MLKL‐inhibitor, GW806742X, also inhibits RIPK1 kinase activity. Despite activation of the full RIPK1‐RIPK3‐MLKL pathway, we see no increase in cell death in the DCs. This indicates a unique phenotype imposed in DCs upon necroptotic pathway activation, making DCs able to mature and induce a potent immune response without dying themselves.

We observe a high level of STING phosphorylation with concomitant increase in TBK1 phosphorylation when the DCs are co‐treated with zVAD and cGAMP. Likewise, DC maturation was increased in the combinational treatment compared with mono‐treatments. Interestingly, activation of the STING pathway seen by phosphorylation, is sustained at a high level, still present 24 h after stimulation upon co‐treatment. To our surprise, we did not see a reduction in STING protein level in cGAMP‐stimulated BMDCs. However, this has also been observed in other studies on BMDCs [31, 32]. Upon STING activation, RIPK3 can be activated by autologously produced IFN‐I and TNF‐α, mediating sustained STING activation by preventing STING autophagy [8]. It is likely that the observed long stability of STING is caused by RIPK3 activation.

In the TME, there is a substantial amount of cell death with the release of immune‐stimulating molecules, including DNA and possibly cGAMP, which can affect the activity of tumor‐infiltrating immune cells [1]. Elevated cell death in tumors can lead to an antitumoral immune reaction, which likely contributes to the effect of conventional cancer therapies such as chemotherapy and radiotherapy [1]. A therapeutic caspase inhibition has the potential to induce necroptosis in cancer cells and, at the same time, activate intratumoral DCs. We investigated the effect of caspase inhibition in co‐cultures with DCs and L929 cancer cells and showed that this leads to cell death in the L929 cells, while no death is induced in the DCs. Under normal in vitro induction of necroptosis, other factors such as TNF‐α are necessary to drive the response [33]. We show that no additional signal is needed for the induction of L929 cell death when these are co‐cultured with DCs, which could be due to cytokines secreted from the DCs that deliver the extra signal to the L929 cells. Indeed, we observed a secretion of the NF‐κB and ISG‐regulated cytokine, CXCL10, upon DC maturation. Moreover, we find that adding supernatant from mature DC cultures to L929 cells with concomitant zVAD stimulation is sufficient to drive L929 cell death, and the effect was inhibited by the addition of a TNFR1‐blocking antibody, indicating that the co‐stimulatory signal is DC‐derived TNF‐α. Interestingly, we found that the DC supernatant combined with zVAD did not induce L929 cell death when DCs were pretreated with the GW806742X, indicating that the effect was dependent on nonnecroptotic RIPK1‐RIPK3‐MLKL activity in the DCs. Other nonnecroptotic functions of the pathway have previously been described; however, not in DCs [6, 34].

Necroptotic cancer cells are known to be able to activate DCs and induce antitumor immunity [35]. We investigated the effect of stimulating DCs with medium from apoptotic or necroptotic cells, which showed that the supernatant from necroptotic cells is sufficient to induce a maturation response in the DCs, indicating that factors secreted or released by the necroptotic cells are influencing DC maturation. Necroptotic cells are known to release several DAMPs, including DNA, “find me” signals, alarmins, and heat‐shock proteins [36].

Overall, these findings illustrate a synergistic effect of the STING pathway and non‐cell death effects of the necroptosis pathway in DCs, ultimately leading to the induction of necroptosis in cancer cells. Our findings add to the understanding of necroptosis‐independent function of the RIPK1‐RIPK3‐MLKL axis and indicate a double function of necroptosis signaling in cancer regulation, where it has opposite effects on cancer cells and DCs. These results give rise to potential exploitation in a therapeutic setting, by the combination of already existing cell death‐inducing therapeutics and caspase inhibitors.

sec.title: Cell Cultures
sec.p: The murine fibroblast cancer cell line L929 (kindly provided by Prof. Søren R. Paludan, Aarhus University, Denmark) was grown in DMEM (Gibco) supplemented with 10% heat‐inactivated (HI) FBS, 2 mM L‐glutamine, 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 µg/mL streptomycin and seeded in well plates 24 h prior to stimulation.

The human acute leukemia monocyte cell line THP‐1 WT (ATCC) or THP‐1 STING KO clones [37] were grown in RPMI 1640 (Gibco) supplemented with 10% HI FBS, 2 mM l‐glutamine, 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 µg/mL streptomycin. The STING KO medium was supplemented with 1 µg/mL pyromycin (Sigma‐Aldrich). To generate macrophage‐like cells, the THP‐1 cells were treated with Phorbol 12‐myristate 13‐acetate (PMA) overnight, followed by medium change and a resting period of 24 h prior to stimulation.

MoDCs were generated from human monocytes, purified from whole blood from three different healthy donors. PBMCs were separated from whole blood using Lymphoprep (Stemcell Technologies) gradient centrifugation, and monocytes were then isolated using a magnetic untouched isolation kit (Miltenyi Biotec), following the manufacturer's instructions. Monocytes were grown in RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% HI FBS, 2 mM L‐glutamine, 100 U/mL penicillin and 100 µg/mL streptomycin, 1000 IU/mL hGM‐CSF (Miltenyi Biotec), and 400 IU/mL hIL‐4 (Miltenyi Biotec) for 7 days. At day 3, extra medium was added to the Petri dishes.

BMDCs were generated from hematopoietic stem cells from 8‐week‐old female mice of the BALB/cJRj or C57BL/6J strains (purchased from Janvier Laboratories, France) approved by the Danish Animal Experiments Inspectorate (license number: 2021‐15‐0201‐00852). After euthanization, the bone marrow (BM) cells were extracted by flushing the tibia and femur. The cells were washed in PBS and transferred to cell culture Petri dishes (Nunc) or frozen in FBS + 7,5% DMSO at −140°C until further use. C57BL/6J STING‐deficient BM cells (Tmem −/−) were kindly provided by Prof. Søren R. Paludan, Aarhus University, Denmark. BM cells were grown in RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% HI FBS, 2 mM L‐glutamine, 100 U/mL penicillin and 100 µg/mL streptomycin, 40 ng/mL rmGM‐CSF (Miltenyi Biotec), 1 ng/mL rmIL‐4 (Miltenyi Biotec), and 50 µM β‐mercaptoethanol for 10 days. At day 3, extra medium was added to the Petri dishes, and on days 5 and 7, half the medium was changed. On day 10, suspension cells and loosely adherent cells were gently washed off the Petri dish, followed by gentle rinsing of the Petri dish with PBS. The cells were centrifuged, and new complete medium containing 20 ng/mL rmGM‐CSF and 1 ng/mL rmIL‐4 was added, and the cells were seeded in well plates. All cells were grown in a humidified incubator, 5% CO2, 37°C.

sec.title: Stimulation of Cells
sec.p: Cells were treated with 10 µM cycloheximide (CHX) (Sigma‐Aldrich), zVAD‐fmk (zVAD) (InvivoGen), or Caspase‐8 Inhibitor II (Caspase‐8 Inhib) (Sigma‐Aldrich) at concentrations indicated 15 min before adding 10 ng/mL rmTNF‐α (BioLegend), 10 µM necrostatin‐1 (Sigma‐Aldrich), and/or 2’3’ cGAMP (cGAMP) (InvivoGen) at concentrations indicated and incubated for 24 h unless otherwise indicated. Stimulation with 100 ng/mL LPS was included as a positive maturation control.
When blocking TNFR1, 100 µg/mL TNFR1 blocking antibody (clone 55R‐170, Thermo Fisher Scientific) was added 4 h prior to stimulation of cells.
For some experiments, the MLKL‐inhibitor, GW806742X (Sigma‐Aldrich), was added to the cells 1 h prior to stimulation at a concentration of 0.1 µM.
In the indicated experiments, 1 µg/mL DNase I (Sigma‐Aldrich) was added to the cells 2 h prior to stimulation.

sec.title: Cell Death
sec.p: L929 cells were seeded and cultured to 80% confluence before the addition of cell death‐inducing reagents. Apoptosis was induced by treatment with 10 ng/mL rmTNF‐α + 10 µM CHX for 24 h. Necroptosis was induced by stimulation with 10 ng/mL TNF‐α + 10 µM zVAD and incubated for 24 h. Supernatant was harvested from the L929 cultures and centrifuged at 300×g for 10 min, and added to immature dendritic cell cultures in a 50/50 (v/v) ratio, followed by incubation for 24 h before maturation analysis.

For L929 cells treated with BMDC supernatants, L929 cells were washed once, resuspended in complete DC medium, and treated with zVAD or left untreated for 15 min. Next, supernatant from BMDC cultures incubated for 24 h with stimuli indicated was added to the L929 cells in a 50/50 (v/v) ratio, and cells were incubated for 24 h. Viability was assessed using eFlour780 staining and analyzed by flow cytometry.

sec.title: L929 Cell and BMDC co‐culture
sec.p: L929 cells were stained with CellTrace CFSE Cell Proliferation dye (Thermo Fisher Scientific) according to the manufacturer's instructions and subsequently seeded in 24‐well plates and cultured to 80% confluence. At day 10 of BMDC culture, BMDCs were harvested as described. The medium of the L929 culture wells was changed to DC complete medium, and BMDCs were added, followed by stimulation with 10 µM zVAD, and the co‐cultures were then incubated for 24 h.

sec.title: IFN‐α/β Bioassay on THP‐1 Macrophage Supernatants
sec.p: HEK‐Blue IFN‐α/β cells (InvivoGen) were cultured in DMEM supplemented with 10% HI FBS, 2 mM L‐glutamine, 50 U/mL penicillin, 50 µg/mL streptomycin, 100 µg/mL normocin, 30 µg/mL blasticidin, and 100 µg/mL zeocin for at least 2 days before experiments. Upon experiments, the medium was no longer supplemented with zeocin and blasticidin. Cells were seeded in flat 96‐well plates and mixed with THP‐1 supernatants. Wells with recombinant human IFN‐α (Abcam) were included to generate a standard curve, and plates were incubated overnight at 37°C. Quanti‐Blue solution (InvivoGen) was added to new flat 96‐well plates, and supernatant from the HEK‐Blue cells was added to the Quanti‐Blue plates and incubated at 37°C for 30 min. Plates were analyzed on a spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific) at 620–655 nm.

sec.title: Flow Cytometry
sec.p: Cells were washed in PBS and then stained in Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780 (Thermo Fisher Scientific) in PBS for 30 min at 4°C and washed in PBS and then again in flow buffer (PBS, 0.1% BSA, 0.01% Sodium Azide). Cells were stained with antibodies for 30 min at 4°C. Antibodies used for staining human moDCs were mouse IgG1 κ anti‐human HLA‐DR‐PE (clone L203, RnD systems), mouse IgG1 κ anti‐human CD83‐PE‐Cy7 (clone HB15e, BD Bioscience), mouse IgG1 κ anti‐human CD86‐BV421 (clone 2331, BD Bioscience), and mouse IgG1 κ isotype controls PE, PE/Cy7, or BV421 (BD Bioscience). Antibodies used for staining murine BMDCs were rat IgG2b κ anti‐mouse MHC II (I‐A/I‐E)‐PE (clone M5/114.15.2, eBioscience, Thermo Fisher Scientific), rat IgG2a κ anti‐mouse CD86‐eFluor450 (clone GL1, eBioscience, Thermo Fisher Scientific), rat IgG2a κ anti‐mouse CD40‐APC (clone IC10, eBioscience, Thermo Fisher Scientific), rat IgG2b isotype control PE (eBioscience, Thermo Fisher Scientific), and rat IgG2a κ isotype controls APC or eFluor450 (eBioscience, Thermo Fisher Scientific). Cells were fixed in 1% formaldehyde in PBS and stored at 4°C for a maximum of 1 week before analysis using a Cytoflex S2 cytometer (Beckman Coulter).

Cells were gated using FSC‐A‐SSC‐A, singlets were isolated using FSC‐A‐FSC‐H, and live cells were gated using APC‐750‐SSC‐A. 10,000 live cells were recorded for each sample and analyzed using FlowJo v10. Flow cytometry data show (unless otherwise stated) median fluorescence intensity (MFI) normalized to UT.

sec.title: Western Blotting
sec.p: Cells were lysed in ice‐cold RIPA lysis and extraction buffer (Thermo Fisher Scientific), with Complete protease inhibitor cocktail (Sigma‐Aldrich), Pierce protease and phosphatase inhibitor (Thermo Fisher Scientific), 10 mM sodium fluoride, and Benzonase (Sigma‐Aldrich).
Protein concentration of lysates was determined using Pierce BCA protein assay kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific) according to the manufacturer's instructions.

The lysates were denatured in either 2x Laemmli buffer (BioRad) with DTT or 4x XT sample buffer (BioRad) with 20x detergent (BioRad) and heated for 5 min at 95°C. Samples were loaded at a concentration of 10 µg in 4%–15% Mini‐PROTEAN TGX Precast gels (BioRad) for SDS‐PAGE. Blotting of proteins was performed on 0.2 µm PVDF membranes using a dry Trans‐Blot‐Turbo system (BioRad) or on 0.2 µm nitrocellulose membranes in a TE22 Mighty Small transfer system (Hoefer) containing a 25 mM Tris and 192 mM glycine buffer with 20% ethanol for 100 min at 100 V. Membranes were blocked in Tris buffered Saline with Tween 20 (TBST) and 5 % skim milk at RT for 1 h. Washes were performed using TBST after blocking and between stainings. Primary antibodies were diluted 1:1000 in TBST + 5% skim milk and 0,05% Sodium Azide. All primary antibodies were Rabbit mAb from Cell Signaling Technology unless otherwise stated. Primary antibodies were anti‐RIP (Clone: D94C12), anti‐Phospho‐RIP (Ser166) (Clone: E7G6O), anti‐RIP3 (Clone: D8J3L), anti‐Phospho‐RIP3 (Thr231/Ser232) (Clone: E7S1R), anti‐MLKL (Clone: D6W1K), anti‐phospho‐MLKL (Ser345) (Clone: D6E3G), anti‐STING (clone: D2P2F), anti‐STING (clone: D1V5L), anti‐phospho‐STING (Ser365) (D8F4W), anti‐TBK1/NAK (Clone: E8I3G), anti‐phospho‐TBK1/NAK (Ser172) (Clone: D52C2), and Mouse mAb anti‐GAPDH (Clone: G‐9, Santa Cruz Biotechnology). Secondary antibodies were Swine anti‐Rabbit Immunoglobulins‐HRP (Dako) and Goat anti‐Mouse Immunoglobulins‐HRP (Dako), diluted 1:5000 and 1:20,000, respectively, in TBST + 5 % skim milk. Proteins on membranes were detected using SuperSignal West Femto Maximum Sensitivity substrate (Thermo Fisher Scientific), SuperSignal West Pico PLUS chemiluminescent substrate (Thermo Fisher Scientific), or Clarity Western ECL substrate (BioRad).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: GraphPad Prism version 9.0 was used for statistical analysis. In flow cytometry analyses of cell experiments, differences between multiple groups were analyzed using one‐way ANOVA with Tukey's multiple comparisons. All experiments include triplicates; in flow cytometry, each sample was analyzed separately, while for WB, triplicates were pooled prior to loading the sample on the gel. Figures show representative experiments.

sec.title: Data Limitations and Perspectives
sec.p: Currently, no specific murine MLKL inhibitor exists, which limits the investigations of direct MLKL‐mediated effects in mouse cells. This study employed an MLKL inhibitor, GW806742X, which also targets the kinase activity of RIPK1, and the observed effects may be influenced by the lack of RIPK1 kinase activity beyond activation of RIPK3‐MLKL signaling. The study was performed using murine BMDCs and human moDCs as a source of DCs. Fully differentiated DCs extracted from mice will typically contain large amounts of mature DCs that have matured in response to extraction and handling. This limits the usability of these cells in the current study, which needs DCs with a completely immature phenotype.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Trine S Jensen: Conceptualization, methodology, analysis, data interpretation, writing original draft, review, and editing. Marlene F Laursen: Methodology, analysis, data interpretation, review, and editing. Lea Schort: Methodology, analysis, review, and editing. Agnieszka Banasik: Methodology, analysis, review, and editing. Ralf Agger: Data interpretation, review, and editing. Martin R Jakobsen: Conceptualization, data interpretation, funding acquisition, review, and editing. Emil Kofod‐Olsen: Conceptualization, analysis, data interpretation, funding acquisition, writing original draft, review, and editing.

sec.title: Conflicts of Interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

sec.title: Peer Review
sec.p: The peer review history for this article is available at https://publons.com/publon/10.1002/eji.70044.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank Brita Holst Serup for technical assistance. Funding: this work was funded by the Novo Nordic Foundation (EKO and MRJ), Else og Mogens Wedell‐Wedellborgs Fond (EKO), Eva og Henry Frenkels Mindelegat (EKO), and Fabrikant Einar Willumsens Mindelegat (EKO).

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: The data supporting the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
